awd_titl_txt: Louis Stokes Mississippi Alliance for Minority Participation (LSMAMP) Pathways Alliance
awd_abstract_narration:
The Louis Stokes Mississippi STEM Pathways and Research Alliance is a comprehensive statewide program that is designed to support broad-based STEM education and to provide pathways to STEM careers in all geographical areas of the state of Mississippi.  This alliance is comprised of nine (9) post-secondary institutions that have a long history of cooperation through collective sharing of resources combined with individual institutional strengths. The institutions include Jackson State University (the lead institution), the University of Mississippi, Mississippi State University, Alcorn State University, Mississippi Valley State University, the University of Southern Mississippi, Tougaloo College, Delta State University, and Hinds Community College. The alliance will recruit and support the economically disadvantaged minority student population throughout the state. The support provided by NSF has been, and will continue to be instrumental to the training of students unrepresented in STEM from undergraduate through graduate programs.  Many Mississippi students enrolled in STEM disciplines will likely change their majors after the first year in college. LS-MAMP will develop pathways for successful, recruitment, retention and transition of students to STEM majors and will aid in changing these patterns for a significant number of URM students in the region. These efforts will be carried out through programmatic activities such as mentoring, intrusive intervention, legislative changes,  (2+2) community college program and transfers, conferences, expert speakers, summer internships, advising and many other activities to improve upon these successes and to retain and graduate these enthusiastic yet less prepared STEM students from undergraduate to graduate and to STEM fields. 


The need for a strong, strategic, and productive STEM graduate pipeline within the state cannot be overemphasized.  The alliance will continue to provide opportunities for students and equip them with the foundation necessary to tackle the states' and the nation's science and technology needs and challenges. The scientific and technological needs of the nation as well as the unique opportunity presented by the demographics and educational needs of the state makes the alliance a strong partner of the National Science Foundation. The mission of the Mississippi STEM Pathways and Research Alliance will be accomplished by  1). Increasing undergraduate STEM enrollment and recruitment by 35% and increasing STEM retention and baccalaureate graduation by 30% over the next five years, 2).  Increasing the number of students matriculating into STEM graduate program pipelines by 25% over the next five years, 3). Increasing the production and dissemination of scholarly research on broadening participation of URM students in STEM discipline, 4). Increasing the number of students gaining international research experiences from 20 to 30 students annually, 5). Providing mentoring and STEM research experiences for students through partnerships with national laboratories, industry, out-of-state universities, and scientific societies, 6), Supporting the alliance initiatives via continued institutionalization. (7). Engaging in educational research that will provide a sustainable institution-wide model to highlight high impact best practices, and control group study to drastically improve the graduation rates of URM students in STEM fields.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Div. of Equity for Excellence in STEM

por.por_cntn:
Mississippi Alliance Outcome Report

This last funding cycle for the  Louis Stoke  Mississippi Alliance for Minority Participation(LMAMP) has been a great journey for the participating students, faculty and staff alike. Below are some of the notable accomplishments and outcomes.

(1).  Alliance Community College Transfers: This cycle the Alliance  had an average of 555 STEM students transfers per year from community colleges,  for a total of 2,772 to the alliance institutions in STEM. The LS-MAMP alliance carried out STEM career fairs, workshops, symposium, and mentorship at the community colleges and alliance community to expose students to the STEM fields. The Alliance had success in this area.

 (2). Collaboration with Mississippi Academy Of Sciences (MAS): LSMAMP has been  collaborating and organizing its Symposium  annually in conjunction with Mississippi Academy of Sciences meetings. As a result, not only did the students benefit from the Symposium, but they also attend scientific presentations by experienced scientists and interact with them. The LSMAMP students and faculty presented an average of 37 oral and 185 poster presentations at these events. This timing pattern of the Symposium has been very cost-effective and has had synergic outcomes for professional development and exposure to the academic research enterprise. LSMAMP and the Mississippi Academy of Sciences are mutually excited about this collaboration and continuation.

(3)  Alliance Abstract  286 Presentations for 2024 and more than 700 presentations over the five years of the grant:  Alliance students and faculty presented 286 oral and poster presentations at conferences(2024). This is as a result of the collaborating with the Mississippi Academy of sciences.  Students were exposed to cutting edge research and researchers, networking accessibility and collaborations of students and faculty members with students from  other institutions. Blow are the number of presentations at conferences.

Jackson State University

41

Alcorn State University

43

Delta State University

12

Mississippi State University

74

Mississippi Valley State University

12

Tougaloo college

23

University of Mississippi

18

University of Southern Mississippi

63

Total Number of Submitted Abstracts

286

(4) The Post-Baccalaureate Research Experience for LSAMP Students (PRELS):

This program is an excellent program that exposed graduating underserved students to the importance of research, intensive hands-on lab experience to train, support, prepare them for graduate school and the workforce. Currently, of the 11 students that were enrolled in the program, 10 are entering STEM graduate programs and one is entering the workforce.

(5).  Research Publications in Referred Journals: The Educational Research Component of the Alliance published two articles in the journal below.

  • A. Felix.A. Okojie et. all. “A Mixed Method Study of Factors that Enhance Louis Stokes Mississippi Alliance for Minority Participation (LSMAMP)           Students Degree Attainment in STEM”.  Journal of the Mississippi Academy of Sciences, Vol.66, N0.1 2021.
  • B. Felix A, Okojie, et. all. “ A Phenomenological Study of Factors the Enhance Louise Stokes Mississippi Alliance for Minority Participation (LSMAMP) Students Persistence and Degree Attainment in STEM” Journal of Education and Human Development, Vol. 10 No4, December 2021.

 

Note: Findings, and conclusions or recommendations expressed in this Report are those of the PI and do not necessarily reflect the views of the National Science Foundation. "NSF has not approved or endorsed the content of this report".


Last Modified: 07/03/2024
Modified by: Felix A Okojie
